Today, Jacqueline is requesting a Kiva loan so that she can start running a business of Mobile money transfers. She has successfully completed her training and is ready to get started. Her business will provide the people in Blantyre an easy way to send and receive money.

With the loan, Jacqueline will be able to insure that she has money to serve customers. The loan will also help her to purchase a trading kiosk, a chair where she can sit as she attends to customers, a cashbox where she can keep her money safe and a phone which she will use to serve her customers. Jacqueline is excited for the opportunity to become a Mobile money transfer business owner. She says her life will change once she starts earning a bit more money as she will be able to contribute more at home and hopefully improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to set up her own Zoona mobile money transfer business by providing the funds needed to serve customers and purchasing the equipment needed for her to start transacting.

loans.name: Alinafe

texts.en:
Alinafe is 21 years old. She is passionate about rural and community development and she loves to volunteer at the local youth center. She is the second born in a family of four. Alinafe has completed training with Zoona to start running her own Zoona mobile money transfer business in her hometown of Blantyre in Malawi. Her business will provide the services of sending and receiving money to a lot of people in her community. 

Alinafe is requesting a loan to help her start her business. This loan will help Alinafe pay for her set up costs. She will be able to purchase a trading kiosk, a mobile phone to be used to serve her customers, a chair where she can sit as she serves her customers, and a cash box where she can keep her cash for safety. This loan will also provide Alinafe with the float needed for her to serve her customers. 

Zoona has done market research in the area where Alinafe is going to set up and has determined that the location for this kiosk is ideal. Alinafe will be one of the main operators of Zoona mobile money transfers in Blantyre and a large number of families will be using her service to send and receive their monies. 

Alinafe’s dream is to help fellow youths in the country by creating employment. She explains that she is passionate about helping people, and employment in Malawi is very scarce and that by starting her own business, she will hopefully be able to empower other young people. Alinafe finished high school in 2011 and went to college to study rural and community development, but did not complete her course because she did not have the financial support. With her business, she hopes to one day go back to college and complete her education. Alinafe thanks the Kiva lenders

loans.use: to pay for her set up costs such as float, a trading kiosk, an internet enabled phone, a cashbox and chair where she can sit as she serves customers.

loans.name: Ylber

texts.en:
Ylber wants to buy potato seeds for planting; the season to plant potatoes has already started.

Ylber is about 54 years old and is a married father of a 24-year-old child. For the past almost 24 years, he’s been focusing on agriculture activity as the only source of income for his family. In the summer months, he goes to Greece for seasonal work; this way he makes a little cash on the side.

Ylber’s family owns about 16 dynym (about 3.5 acres) of agricultural land where they plant beans and potatoes to sell and wheat for their family use. Since the village doesn't have a very cold climate like the rest of the region, their focus has been on grapevines as well, in addition to planting veggies and crops.

loans.use: to pay for potato seeds to plant

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en:
Meet Abigail, 23 years old. She comes from a family of eight children. She lives with her late sister’s son and helps take care of him by selling cassava. This is not enough for her to meet their basic needs. Abigail needs a Kiva loan to start running her own Zoona mobile money transfer business in the town of Namitete, Malawi. Her business will provide financial services to people in her community. 

Abigail describes herself as a hardworking businesswoman who has been through some difficult times, having lost both her parents at a very young age. Currently, Abigail runs a small business, selling cassava. She goes round the community carrying her merchandise, as she does not have a shop. She is excited to start running her Zoona mobile money transfer business, as she will have a place to sit and customers will come to her to send and receive money. 

Abigail is requesting a loan in order to get the working capital she needs to get her Zoona business off the ground and start serving her community. With this loan, Abigail will pay for her set-up costs. This loan will be used to buy a branded trading kiosk, framed fee posters, and some uniforms. She will also buy an Internet-enabled mobile phone, a cashbox and chair. Half of the funds will be used as float to serve her customers. 

The profits from her business will help Abigail to provide better for herself and her nephew whom she plans to employ once her business starts to grow.

loans.use: To set up her own business of sending and receiving money in Namitete, Malawi

loans.name: Bright

texts.en:
Bright is 28 years old. He is from Mulanje, a town in the southern regions of Malawi, known for the Mulanje Massif. Bright has worked for several companies and he branched out as an entrepreneur. Bright will be relocating from his hometown to a town called Thyolo, where he will set up his business. He is excited to start running his own Zoona mobile money transfer business because it will provide access to financial services to people in the community of Thyolo, who previously had to travel long distances in order to send or receive money. Bright will work hard to ensure that the business is successful. He says the community will benefit because there are few companies in Malawi that provide financial services that actually work. He says most of the people, especially in rural communities, struggle to access proper financial services. He hopes that through his business, he will be able to create employment for other young people.

Bright is requesting a loan in order to get the working capital he needs to get his Zoona business off the ground and start serving his community. With this loan, he will pay for his set-up costs. This loan will be used to buy a branded trading kiosk, framed fee posters, and some uniforms. He will also buy an Internet-enabled mobile phone, a cash-box and a chair. He will use half of the funds from this loan as float for him to serve his customers. Bright is hopeful that the anticipated profits from his business will help him pay for his siblings’ school fees and provide for their basic needs.

loans.use: to set up his own Zoona mobile money transfer business by providing the funds needed to serve customers and purchasing the equipment needed for him to start transacting.

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark is 32 years old. He is an emerging entrepreneur from Mitundu located in Lilongwe district, Malawi. He has recently completed training to start running his own business of mobile money transfers. His business will provide mobile money services to people who need to access financial services in his community.

 Mark is excited about the prospect of running his own business. He says his life will change once he starts running his own Zoona mobile money transfer business, as he will be able to provide for his basic needs and send money back home to his parents and siblings. Mark says his community will also benefit, as they will have access to easy and safe financial transactions that will enable them to move their monies without having to wait for days to access services. 

Mark is requesting a loan to set up his business, so that he can provide financial services to people in Mitundu. With this loan, he will be able to purchase a Zoona branded kiosk, a mobile phone, a chair and a cashbox. The loan will also ensure that Mark has money to serve his customers. The kiosk will be used to serve customers in Mitundu, as a large number of people are unbanked. Mark will be one of the main operators of Zoona mobile money transfers in town, and a large number of families will be using his service. 

Mark is grateful for this opportunity and thanks the Kiva lenders for their help. His biggest dream is to run a successful business that makes people’s lives easier.

loans.use: to set up a business of mobile money transfers, so that he can provide financial services to people in Mitundu, Lilongwe.

loans.name: Reyhema

texts.en:
Meet 24-year-old Reyhema. She is the first born in a family of four. As the first born, Reyhema is responsible for her siblings.  She comes from Lewonde and will be relocating to Monkey Bay to make her dream of running her own business a reality. She needs a loan to make this happen.

Reyhema is very excited to start running her own mobile money transfer business. She sees it as a great opportunity to empower her family and her community at large. Before Reyhema started running her own business, she studied Business Administration. She believes that her studies will be instrumental in running her business, as she will be able to apply some of the principals she learned in her course.  

Reyhema will use this loan to purchase a trading kiosk, which she will place at one of the most popular supermarkets in Monkey Bay. She will also purchase an Internet enabled phone, which she will use to make her transactions. The loan will also serve as her working capital float for her to serve people in the community who need to access financial services.

Reyhema’s dream is to grow her business and open more outlets, so that she can employ other people. She thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase trading equiment needed for her to start running her own business of mobile money transfers.

loans.name: Franklyn

texts.en:
Franklyn is 22 years old. He is the second born in a family of three. He comes from Dowa, Malawi. He is asking for a loan in order to start running his own business.

Franklyn has completed training with Zoona to set up his own business as a Zoona mobile money transfer agent. This means that Franklyn will be offering the service of mobile money to his community and earning a profit for each transaction that he makes. He is grateful for the opportunity to start running his own business. He explains that he has always wanted to run a business of his own.

With this loan, Franklyn will be able to serve his customers by providing the float needed for him to make transactions. The loan will also enable him to purchase a trading kiosk, a mobile phone and cashbox. All these are necessary items for him to successfully get his business off the ground.

Franklyn would like to take this opportunity to thank the Kiva lenders for their support. He is hopeful that once he starts running his own business, he can begin to contribute the household and take care of his own basic needs like clothes and food.

loans.use: to purchase a Zoona branded trading kiosk, a mobile phone, a chair and a cashbox. It will also enable him to serve customers.

loans.name: Natia

texts.en:
Natia is a 33-year-old housekeeper who takes care of two school-aged daughters. Her husband is the only breadwinner in the family; he works as a private artisan. He gets unstable income of approximately 300 GEL per month; that is really hardly enough to even cover the basic needs of the family. 

Natia wants to do her bit for the family's welfare, and start her own business. All the financial institutions rejected her loan requests because of her unstable financial conditions and lack of experience.  After several unsuccessful attempts, Natia applied for the credit from MFO Credo. Her request was approved in the framework of the Start Up program, which is joint initiative with Kiva, permitting people to start or re-start businesses. 

With the received credit, Natia will purchase all equipment and tools and will open a beauty salon at the good location of town. She will get the business income and have her own costumers among local people.
 
The Start Up credit will be a great support for the family, as their income will be significantly increased via Kiva lenders. 

Natia has a great desire to get her children a good education for progressing in life.  She is thankful to Kiva lenders for giving her a chance to become financially independent.

loans.use: To open beauty salon

loans.name: Steven

texts.en:
Steven is 34 years old. He is married and has two children, ages 5 and 2 years old. He works very hard to support his family.

Steven recently completed training with Zoona to start running his own business as a mobile money transfer agent. This means Steven will provide the service of sending and receiving money to people in his community. This service is very important as a large number of people in Blantyre, Malawi are do not have banks. This makes moving their monies a challenge, as they have to use unsafe means like bus services. Steven will make a profit from each transaction that he makes. 

Steven needs the loan to start running the business. The loan will help him to purchase a trading kiosk, where he will serve his customers. He will also be able to purchase an Internet enabled phone, which will help him facilitate the transactions. The money will also enable Steven to serve his customers as working float.  Float is essential for Steven to run his business successfully, as this is the money that he will use to payout customers who need to receive money.

Steven thanks the Kiva lenders for the opportunity to start running his own business and improve his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase neccessary equipment needed for him to start offering mobile money services

loans.name: Dalitso

texts.en:
Dalitso is 20 years old. She is a single mother to her 1 and a half-year-old daughter. She is the last-born in a family of seven, and lives with her parents in Blantyre Malawi. She is requesting a loan to start running her own Zoona mobile money transfer business in Blantyre.

Dalitso completed her high school and enrolled in college to obtain a certificate in computer studies. Unfortunately, she did not complete her course, due to a lack of money to pay for her college fees. Today, Dalitso is excited to start running her own business. Her business will provide financial services to unbanked people in her community. People will go to Dalitso’s shop to send and receive money. From the transactions, she will earn her profits. With the profits, she hopes to move out of her parent’s house with her daughter.

This loan will help Dalitso set up her business by purchasing a trading kiosk, an Internet enabled phone, a cashbox and a chair. She will also use the money as float to serve her customers.

loans.use: to set up her business by purchasing a trading kiosk, an Internet enabled phone, a cashbox, a chair and provide for float.

loans.name: Kizito

texts.en:
Kizito is 46 years old. He lives with his wife and their three children in Chinteche, Malawi. All his children go to school. 

Kizito is requesting a loan in order to start running his own Zoona mobile money transfer business in his hometown of Chintenche.

Kizito has successfully completed training with Zoona to set up his own kiosk as a mobile money transfer agent.  This means that Kizito will provide the service of mobile money transfers and earn profit from the business every time a customer sends and receives money from his kiosk. He is very excited about the prospect of running his own business and earning money, as this will help him provide for his family.

Kizito’s community does not have a bank. They rely on a mobile truck that comes to the small town two times a week to provide them with their banking needs. This makes it very difficult for people to make day-to-day transactions. Kizito is excited to open a Zoona mobile money transfer business because it will help his community move their monies in a safe and convenient manner. He says his community will benefit because they will not have to go to the next town to transact on a daily basis, as the service will now be on their doorstep.

Zoona has done extensive research in Kizito’s community and has determined that the location for the mobile money transfer business is ideal. The closest bank is about 79km away in a town called Mzuzu, and most clients rely on the mobile truck, which comes twice weekly. Since most clients walk or use their bicycles to travel, it is certain they will prefer to use Kizito’s mobile money transfer kiosk rather than traveling a longer distance and waiting for the specific banking days. 

This loan will help Kizito start his own business, with the loan, he will be able to purchase the equipment needed for him to run the mobile money transfer business. He will purchase a trading kiosk where he will serve his customers, and an Internet enabled phone, which he will use to transact. This loan will also insure that Kizito has a basic float for him to serve his customers.

Kizito would like to thank the Kiva lenders for the opportunity to run his own business. He is hopeful that by earning some money, he can improve his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase the equipment such as a trading kiosk, phone, cashbox and float

loans.name: Bornface

texts.en:
Bornface is an emerging entrepreneur, aged 24. He comes from a family of six children and is the fifth born. He needs a loan to start running his own Zoona mobile money transfer business.

Bornface has completed training with Zoona to start running his own business. He will be relocating from his hometown to Malosa; Zomba to set up his business there. He is excited to move, as the move will give him a chance to get his own place and earn a living. 

Bornface is currently unemployed and struggles to provide basic needs for himself. He sees the opportunity to start running his own business as a step in the right direction. He explains that he did not complete high school and getting a job is a challenge. He has decided to focus his energies on becoming a successful businessman.

Bornface will use the loan to serve his customers who need to send and receive money from his kiosk. He will also use the money to purchase the trading kiosk where he will operate. With the loan, Bornface will also be able to purchase an Internet enabled phone, a chair and cashbox. All these are necessary for Bonface to be able to run his mobile money transfer business. He will earn his profits from each transaction that he makes.

Bornface thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a trading kiosk, phone, chair and cashbox

loans.name: Zoya

texts.en:
Here is Zoya, 40 years old. She is from Sisavan village, Ararat region. She lives with her husband and daughter. Her only son currently serves in the army.

Zoya takes care of her household as well as their family farm. On her farm she takes care of 70 sheep, as well as perfectly cares for her land.  She cultivates potatoes, eggplant and sunflowers. On her small but beautiful orchard, Zoya also grows two apricot, apple and pear trees. She sells her farm products locally and gets income for the family's living. 

Zoya has dream of enlarging her farm, and hopes that Kiva lenders will support her loan to be funded. Zoya plans to purchase 16 sheep for enlarging the herd. 

As this is her first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history.

loans.use: to pay for 16 sheep for enlarging the herd

loans.name: Handson

texts.en:
Handson is 61 years old, married to Joyce, and they are blessed with six children. He has been in the farming business for the last 12 years, and earns KES 15,000 per month.

Handson has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow to increase his income by supplying milk to his customers. He plans to use the anticipated profits to start a retail shop in the area and also buy a plot for settlement.

His future hope is to expand his dairy farming business and be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase rice, milk, sugar, cooking fat and charcoal.

loans.name: Nyawa

texts.en:
Nyawa is a married woman and has been blessed with three children, all of whom attend school. Together with her husband, they live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She has operated a business selling fish for over five years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. She faces major challenges of seasonality and perishability, leading to losses.
With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase bundles of fish to sell. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish to sell.

loans.name: Wonadia Group

texts.fr: Marie, membre représentatif du groupe est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle fait le commerce du savon. Elle a besoin de ce crédit pour acheter du savon au prix d'en gros pour vendre en détail à sa clientèle. Le savon est indispensable pour les ménages donc le commerce de Marie est bien ciblé.Le groupe Wonadia est à son 11ème contrat de prêt avec notre institution. Ce groupe fait ses remboursements toujours à la bonne date. A l'issue des ventes son bénéfice lui permettra d'aider son époux dans la gestion de la famille et continuer son activité.
texts.en:
Marie, the member representing this group, is married and the mother of six children. She sells soap. She needs a loan to buy soap at wholesale prices so as to resell it retail to her clientele. Soap is indispensable to households, so Marie's business is right on target.

The Wonadia group is on its 11th loan contract with ACFIME. This group always makes its repayments on time. After her sales have been made, Marie's profit will allow her to help her husband manage the family expenses and continue her activity.

loans.use: to buy soap wholesale to resell retail

loans.name: Ireen

texts.en:
Ireen is 25 years old. She is single and lives with her sister in a household of eight. Ireen is requesting a loan in order to start running her own Zoona mobile money transfer business in Mzimba, Malawi. The business will provide financial services to people in the community. When Ireen receives the loans she will use these funds to purchase a Zoona branded kiosk, some branded fee posters, a web-enabled mobile phone, a chair and a cash box. The loan will also provide Ireen with the funds to serve her customers.

Ireen is excited by this opportunity with Zoona because it will allow her to serve her community and provide them with much needed access to financial services. She will set up her business in Mzimba, located in the Northern region of Malawi. This location is key, as most of its population is unbanked. By setting up in Mzimba, Ireen will provide much-needed financial services to her community.

Ireen’s goal is to grow her business and employ other people so that she can study part time and pursue a bachelor’s degree in journalism.

loans.use: to purchase a Zoona branded kiosk, some branded fee posters, a web-enabled mobile phone, a chair and a cash box. The loan will also provide the funds to serve her customers

loans.name: Alakabon Group

texts.fr: Aminata et les autres membres du groupe Alakabon sont des femmes qui se battent au quotidien pour assurer un bien être à leurs enfants. Elles sont toutes engagées dans le commerce. Aminata, responsable de ce groupe est mariée, mère de 3 enfants. Cette brave dame gère sa propre boutique dans laquelle elle vend divers articles. Par exemple: du savon, du lait, de l'huile, de la mayonnaise, du sucre,etc. Elle a besoin du crédit pour approvisionner sa boutique. D'ici que Aminata finissent de rembourser son prêt, elle aura une épargne de 30 000 francs CFA dans notre institution et en plus de cela, elle aura un bénéfice qui lui permettra de s'occuper de sa famille et de continuer son activité.
texts.en:
Aminata and the other members of the group called Alakabon are women who struggle daily to ensure the well-being of their children. They are all working in small-scale commerce. 

Aminata, the leader of the group, is married and the mother of three children. This good lady manages her own shop in which she sells various items, for example, soap, milk, oil, mayonnaise, sugar, etc. She needs a loan to restock her store. When Aminata finishes reimbursing her loan, she will have 30,000 francs CFA in savings in ACFIME and moreover, she will have a profit that will allow her to take care of her family and continue her business.

loans.use: to stock her store with merchandise (oil, rice, milk, juices) for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production, to enable him to add more stock to sell at his retail shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production, to enable him produce more milk to sell for the increasing demand for milk in the region.

loans.name: Srbuhi

texts.en:
The nice woman in the photo is Srbuhi. She has been involved in pig breeding and sales for four years. She currently has 13 pigs and 107 piglets on her farm. Srbuhi also works and manages a local laboratory, but since she likes her farming activities, she spends all of her time developing and enlarging it.  Her husband and two sons help her with the farming work.

By applying for this loan, Srbuhi asks lenders to help her in purchasing special forage for her pigs and piglets.  As this is her first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who did not have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history.

loans.use: to pay for special forage for her pigs and piglets.

loans.name: Kaleso

texts.en:
Kaleso is a married woman with six kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

Kaleso operates a grocery stall selling vegetables. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a wholesale business in the future. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase stock of tomatoes, onions and green vegetables. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of tomatoes, onions and green vegetables.

loans.name: Ndegwa

texts.en:
Ndegwa is a married mother of two and lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. She sells green groceries, helped by her family. Ndegwa is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more and save money in order to have a more formal establishment. Ndegwa is requesting a loan of Kes 50,000 to purchase beans, sugar, oil, vegetables, tomatoes, and onions. She decided to join Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase beans, sugar, oil, vegetables, tomatoes, and onions.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is the first-born in a family of three. He is 22 years old and lives with his parents in a household of five in Blantyre, Malawi. Godfrey completed training with Zoona and is requesting a loan to start running his own Zoona mobile money transfer business in Blantyre. His business will service people in his community who need access to financial services. Godfrey is happy for the opportunity to be connected to Kiva lenders through Zoona. He explains that getting a loan in Malawi is not easy, as they require collateral. He hopes that being connected to the Kiva lenders will help his dream of becoming an entrepreneur become a reality.

Godfrey has requested a loan to access the working capital he needs to get his Zoona business off the ground and start serving his community. With this loan, he will pay for his setup costs, which include buying a branded trading kiosk, framed fee posters, some uniforms, an Internet-enabled mobile phone, a cashbox and a chair. The money will also be used as a float for him to serve his customers. He hopes that through his Zoona mobile money transfer business, he will be able to provide employment for his fellow youths. Godfrey will use the anticipated profits from his business to provide basic needs for himself. He thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: pay for his setup costs, which include buying a branded trading kiosk, framed fee posters, some uniforms, an Internet-enabled mobile phone, a cash box and a chair.

loans.name: Chifundo

texts.en:
Chifundo is a 26-year-old businesswoman. She is single and comes from a family of three. She lives in Lilongwe with her younger brother and helps provide for her family. She will be relocating to a town called Dowa where she will set up her business.

Chifundo is requesting a loan to set up a Zoona mobile money transfer business in Dowa. She started running her own business at a very young age. She started selling pots and washing powder so that she could pay for her rentals and help out at home. The profits from the business were very minimal, as she did not invest a lot of capital due to a lack of funds. Today, Chifundo continues to run her small business. She has seen the opportunity with Zoona and has decided to open her own Zoona mobile money transfer business. She is hopeful that the businesses will give her bigger profit margins so that she can improve her standard of living.

Chifundo will purchase a Zoona branded kiosk, which she will use to serve her customers. She will also use the money to buy a mobile phone, which she will use to facilitate transactions. The rest of the money will be used as her float. Float is the money that Chifundo will use to facilitate the sending and receiving of money from her kiosk. Chifundo’s biggest dream is to grow her business and venture into other businesses like farming.

loans.use: To start running her own business that will provide financial services to people in Dowa, Malawi

loans.name: Pilirani

texts.en:
Pilirani is an emerging entrepreneur. She is a single mother to her three-year-old daughter. She is the fifth born in a family of ten. Pilirani lives at home with her parents in Limbe Township, Blantyre, Malawi. Pilirani is requesting a loan in order to start running her own business so that she can become financially independent.

Pilirani wants to start running a business as a Zoona agent. This means that Pilirani will provide the service of sending and receiving money at her kiosk. She will earn profits on all transactions that go through her kiosk once she sets up. She is very excited for this life changing opportunity and hopes to use the anticipated profits to get her own place with her daughter.

With this loan, Pilirani will be able to purchase a Zoona branded kiosk, a mobile phone, a chair and a cashbox. The loan will also ensure that Pilirani has money to serve her customers. The kiosk will be used to serve customers in Limbe as most of the people are unbanked. Zoona has done market research in Limbe, Blantyre and has determined that the location for this kiosk is ideal. Pilirani will be one of the main operators of Zoona mobile money transfers in town and a large number of families will be using her service. She thanks Kiva and Zoona for this life changing opportunity for her and her daughter.

loans.use: to purchase a Zoona branded kiosk, a mobile phone, a chair and a cashbox and insure that Pilirani has money to serve her customers

loans.name: Mwayi

texts.en:
Mwayi comes from a family of six children. She is 21 years old and loves to create. In her spare time, she can be found making jewelry. She lives with her mother and has always wanted to run her own business. Mwayi just finished training with Zoona so that she can start running her own Zoona mobile money transfer business in Mangochi, Malawi. Mwayi completed her high school education and went to college but due to lack of funds to pay for her school fees, she was forced to drop out in the second semester. Mwayi says her life will change once she starts running her own business because she will be able to provide for her basic needs and help out at home by buying groceries and paying for utility bills.

Mwayi needs a Kiva loan in order to start running her Zoona mobile money transfer business. The loan will be used to provide essential funds needed for her to serve her customers who need to access financial services. She will also use the loan to purchase a trading kiosk, a mobile phone, a chair, and a cash box. All these items are necessary for her to start her business. Mwayi has big dreams for the future. Ever since she dropped out of school, she has never stopped dreaming of creating employment for others. She hopes to grow her business and become an inspiration to other young people.

loans.use: to provide essential funds needed for her to serve her customers and to help her pay for a trading kiosk, a phone, chair and cash box.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en:
Meet 29-year-old Bertha. She is a hardworking mother of four. All her children go to school. She lives in Mchinji with her parents, where she runs a small business selling sausages. She would like to expand her business by adding the business of mobile money transfers so that she can increase her income and provide a better life for her children.

Bertha is excited for the opportunity to run a mobile money transfer business. She will set up her kiosk at a popular supermarket and provide her community with financial services. She will earn profits from every transaction that she makes. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase a trading kiosk, an Internet enabled cell phone, a chair and a cash box. All these are necessary tools for her to start her business. This loan will also provide the working capital needed for Bertha to serve her customers on a daily basis.

Bertha‘s biggest dream is to see all her children complete their education. She explains that she did not have the opportunity to finish hers due to financial constraints, and will continue to work extra hard to make her business successful so that her children do not suffer the same fate.

loans.use: to purchase a trading kiosk, an Internet enabled cell phone, a chair and a cash box so that she can start her own business.

loans.name: Umoja Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Virginia, a member of Umoja Women Group in Nakuru. She is thirty one years old, married and a mother of four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in October 2013.

She does maize and bean farming. Through HiH EA training, she has acquired skills in enterprise development, record keeping and financial management. She has also been able to commercialize her farming and get more profits out of her business.

Virginia is borrowing a Kiva loan to purchase quality fertilizer and seeds for the upcoming planting season. This will greatly boost her farm yield hence increase income which will enable her to provide for her children’s school fees, clothing, food and other needs for the family.

Virginia is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds to help boost farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production to enable him to produce more milk for sale since there is a high demand for milk in the region.

loans.name: Chidiwa

texts.en:
Chidiwa is a married woman and has been blessed with six school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated a dairy farming business, selling at retail and at the market to local residents and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feeds. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feeds.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a married woman with five childen, all of whom attend school. She lives at her a own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a cereal shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Florence dreams of establishing a wholesale cereals shop business in the future.

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 50,000, she wants to purchase stocks of maize, beans and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of maize, beans and wheat flour.

loans.name: Yokasi

texts.en:
Yokasi is a 78 year old, married man living in Fort Portal Uganda. He is a farmer growing food crops like matooke (cooking bananas) and at the same time rears animals like pigs and cattle.

He is faced with the hardship of little capital, that hinders progress in his activities. However, he hopes to have a stable income after working hard and attaining more profits. He has asked for a loan to improve his banana plantation by applying mulch.

loans.use: to improve his banana plantation by applying mulch.

loans.name: Mwero

texts.en:
Mwero is a married woman with four children, all of whom still attend school and are still under her care. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwero operates a clothes selling business, selling at the market to her town dwellers and her neighbours. She cites her major challenge to be the rate of stock turnover which is affected by the seasons.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase one bale of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase one bale of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Dzimba

texts.en:
Dzimba is a married woman and has been blessed with two school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, she has operated a dairy farming business, selling at retail and at the market to local residents and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feed.

loans.name: Ngungo

texts.en:
Ngungo is married and has been blessed with two children who go to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 11 years, she has operated a dairy farming business, selling retail and at the market to her local residents and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of adding more dairy cows, and of expanding with a motorcycle business. With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase medicine for the livestock and feed for the cows. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for her livestock and feed for the cows.

loans.name: Elisabeta

texts.en:
A loan of 200,000 ALL will help Elisabeta stock up on inventory items for her cosmetics store. She has been operating it for the past ten years and already has a clientele buying from her.

Elisabeta is a 33-year-old married mother of three children ranging in age between 3 and 14 years old. Until 2003 they lived in a far northern region that stays covered in snow for about 6 months. Living there is very difficult due to the fact that people cannot plant much and thus, agriculture is not very much developed, and neither is livestock. Not only that, but the roads are not paved and electricity is missing most of the year.

Coming to this current location, their lives have become much better according to Elisabeta. They rent a one bedroom apartment building in their current town where she runs this activity and her husband works for a small income.

loans.use: to buy inventory for her cosmetics store.

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa, a 41-year-old woman from Arshaluys village, lives with her husband and sons. She is involved in farming. Her elder son serves in the army and her second son helps his mom with farming. Larisa specializes in land cultivation. In the early spring, she cultivates cabbage and in the fall, she cultivates potatoes on the same land. Larisa works hard to keep her farming business profitable and help her husband in sustaining their family. 

This is Larisa's first loan and it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who have not have access to traditional credit products before because they have no credit history. Larisa needs to purchase potato seeds and enlarge her cultivation work.

loans.use: to pay for potato seeds

loans.name: Kiletien Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Margaret, of Kiletien Women’s Group. Margaret is 30 years old, married, and has five children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014. 

She does dairy and vegetable farming. She has learned and gained more experience in enterprise start-up and development, and she has also learned skills in financial management, which has helped her to manage her finances well. 

She is borrowing a loan to purchase dairy feed. This will enable her to increase the yield, hence improve her income, and be in a position to educate her children. Margaret is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy dairy feed that will boost farming.

loans.name: Angin

texts.en:
Angin, her husband (in the photo) and their three grown-up sons live in Ararat village. For more than 10 years, the family has cultivated their own arable land near the house where they live. They cultivate peppers, eggplants, greens, and they also keep hens. The requested loan will help this hardworking family develop their farming activities further and enlarge the farm they own. Angin needs the loan to purchase fertilizer and to hire workers for harvesting and cultivation work. 

This is her second loan. Angin has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to the hard work during the recent times, Angin was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and to hire workers for harvesting and cultivation work.

loans.name: Caecilia

texts.en:
This is Caecilia who joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2011. She is 51 years old, married and blessed with three children. She has benefited from the training on enterprise development and saving mobilization courses offered by Hand in Hand Eastern Africa.

She does vegetable farming of potatoes, onions and kale to earn a living. She is requesting a Kiva loan to buy manure and fertilizer that will help improve her crop productivity.This will ensure she maintains a consistent supply of vegetables in the market thus having more income to cater for her family's needs.

Caecilia is grateful to Kiva for the support.

loans.use: to buy manure and fertilizer that will improve her crop productivity.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Mary. She is forty two years old, married and blessed with seven children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014.

After undergoing Hand in Hand Eastern Africa’s training on enterprise development and financial management, Mary started maize and potato farming and also practices poultry keeping.
She is borrowing from Kiva in order to buy fertilizer and seeds so as to increase her farm produce and increase income from the sale of potatoes and maize to her customers. She hopes this extra income will enable her to provide for her family's needs such as food, shelter and school fees for her children.

Mary is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay her loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds that will improve her farm produce.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, sand, gravel, bricks, and other supplies for building an artesian well.

loans.name: Ida Ruth

texts.es:
La socia Ida Ruth se sigue dedicando al negocio de venta de ropa, la socia es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora,el sueño de la socia es tener un local nuevo para vender la ropa. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar zapatos, polos, chompas, polos y blusas.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Ida Ruth continues to manage her clothing business. She is a hardworking and enterprising woman. Her dream is have a new shop where she can sell clothes. She is requesting a loan in order to buy shoes, pullover shirts, sweaters, and blouses.

Ida Ruth is pleased with the loan and promises to complete her payments.

loans.use: to buy shoes, pullover shirts, sweaters, and blouses.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom go to school. Fatuma takes care of one additional family member. 

Fatuma sells second hand-clothes at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the past seven years and works seven days a week. She has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy a bale of second-hand clothes to sell. Her major challenges include seasonality and transportation. 

Fatuma's aspiration is to educate her children to university level. She lives in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Fatuma's major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy a bale of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is 55 years old. He is married and blessed with nine children. He has been a farmer for the past 15 years, and the business earns him a monthly income of KES 9,000. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow to enable him to produce more milk to sell and thus educate his children. 

Evans plans to use his profits to repay the loan and expand his retail business. His hopes for the future are to expand his farming business and be successful.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat is 54 years old and married to Hellen. They are blessed with two children, aged 27 and 15. He has been buying and selling cattle in the market for the past 10 years, earning a monthly income of KES 9,000. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production to enable him to educate his children to higher levels. 

Josephat plans to use his gained profits to repay the loan and expand his business through buying and selling more cattle in the market. His hope is to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production to enable him to educate his children to higher levels

loans.name: Ana Romilia

texts.es:
Ana, está solicitando un nuevo crédito ya que tiene oportunidad de comprar una vaquilla a bajo precio, fortalecerá más su negocio y más delante la podrá comercializar a mejor precio.
El crédito anterior le dio los recursos económicos necesarios para cultivar maíz y comprar alimento para el ganado, teniendo un resultado positivo, ya que su cosecha fue abundante y sin plagas, por otro lado la ganadería está creciendo poco a poco.
texts.en:
Ana is requesting a new loan because she has the opportunity to buy a heifer at a low price. This will strengthen her business even more and will allow her to sell the animal later on at a better price.

Her previous loan gave her the necessary financial resources for cultivating corn and buying food for her cattle. She had positive results since she was able to achieve an abundant harvest without any pests. In addition, her livestock are growing gradually.

loans.use: to buy a heifer at a low price.

loans.name: Aheza Group

texts.en:
AHEZA is a group led by Angelique. The group name means “beautiful” in English. Angelique, who is 40 years old, has a shop and has been in business for the past six years. The group members sell different items, and they have same idea for changing their lives. 

With her portion of the loan, Angelique would like to buy more bread, cooking oil and biscuits to sell. The profits from her business will be used to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more bread, cooking oil and biscuits.

loans.name: Mbodze

texts.en:
Mbodze is a married woman and has been blessed with seven children, all of whom attend school. She and her husband live in their own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Mbodze has operated a fish selling business for over five years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. She faces major challenges of seasonality and perishability, leading to losses.

With the KES 10,000 loan, Mbodze wants to purchase bundles of fish for resale. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish for resale

loans.name: Cruz Del Carmen

texts.es:
Cruz, de 43 años de edad, solo asistió a la primaria, está casada y su esposo trabaja en construcción fuera del país y tienen tres hijos.

Cruz, comenzó desde muy pequeña a trabajar con su familia y cuando se dio la guerra civil de El Salvador, su familia fue de las pocas familias, que se quedaron a vivir en la zona de conflicto.- Actualmente, ella se dedica al comercio de frutas y verduras.

Cruz, necesita el crédito para hacerle reparaciones a su casa, ya que se acerca la temporada de lluviosa y no quiere que su casa se le deteriore más.

Cruz y su esposo sueñan con mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Cruz, 43 years old, only attended elementary school. She is married, and her husband works in construction outside the country. They have three children.

From a very young age, Cruz started working with her family, and when the civil war broke out in El Salvador, her family was one of the few who continued living in the conflict zone. She currently makes her living selling fruits and vegetables.

Cruz needs the loan to make repairs to her house, since the rainy season is approaching, and she doesn't want her house to deteriorate even more.

Cruz and her husband dream about improving their family's living conditions.

loans.use: to make repairs to her house, because the rainy season is approaching, and she doesn't want her house to deteriorate even more.

loans.name: Yenny Yamileth

texts.es:
Yenny, de 28 años de edad, estudio hasta sexto grado, está casada y su esposo se dedica a la agricultura, tienen 2 hijos, todos viven con ellos y estudian.

Yenny, se dedica a los oficios domésticos y a la crianza de ganado, pues su padre le enseño a desempeñar la actividad.- Quiere aprovechar los residuos que genera la agricultura, porque es una persona que se dedica bastante a esta actividad.

Yenny, necesita el crédito para comprar dos vacas lecheras, el préstamo le ayudara a mejorar la ganadería que tiene, además, tendrá mejores ingresos económicos por la venta de leche y queso que producirán las vacas y cubrirá necesidades puntuales que tienen sus hijos. 

Los sueños de Yenny son, son convertirse en una persona emprendedora, que apoya a su familia y uno de sus sueños es poner un negocio propio para salir adelante. También, desea que sus hijos estudien, para que  salgan delante y pretende ampliar su negocio comprando más reces, para mejorar el negocio de venta de lácteos.
texts.en:
Yenny, 28, studied up to the sixth grade.  She is married and her husband works in agriculture.  They have two children, both of whom live with them and study.  

Yenny does the housework, and she also raises livestock, as her father taught her this work. She wants to make use of the agricultural by products, because she does a lot of this work.

Yenny needs the loan in order to purchase two dairy cows, which will help her to improve her livestock.  In addition, she will have better earnings from the sale of milk and cheese that will be produced from the cows, and she will provide for her children’s needs.

Yenny’s dreams are to become a business person who supports her family, and set up her own business in order to get ahead. She also wants her children to study, so that they can get ahead, and she hopes to expand her business, purchasing more cows in order to improve the dairy products sales business.

loans.use: to purchase two dairy cows.

loans.name: Los Jazmines Group

texts.es:
Félix de 35  años de edad, es conviviente con dos hijos menores de edad que aún está en la escuela. Hace cuatro años que él se dedica de administrar su propio negocio de servicio de taxi. Con los ingresos solventa los gastos de su familia. El mayor anhelo de Félix es apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios superiores. El crédito será invertido en el mantenimiento  y compra de llantas de su auto ya que es su herramienta principal de trabajo.
Está muy contento de haber recibido el apoyo de los inversionistas Kiva.
texts.en:
Félix is 35 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has two young children who are in school. For the past four years, he has been managing his own business of providing taxi services. With the income he earns, Félix is able to cover his family’s expenses. His greatest wish is to support his children with their higher education.

The loan will be invested in maintenance and the purchase of tires for his automobile since it is the main piece of equipment that he uses for work.

loans.use: to pay for maintenance and purchase tires for his automobile.

loans.name: La Prosperidad Group

texts.es: Este es la Alcancía Comunal “La Prosperidad”  la cual lo conforma 07 personas responsables y dinámicos. Este es el caso de Ever un joven de 26 años de edad que trata de sacar adelante a sus hermanos menores, es soltero. El lleva más de 01 año dedicándose a la venta de prendas de vestir ambulatoriamente. Su deseo es tener su propio local y seguir progresando para incrementar el volumen de sus productos por temporada de verano-otoño. Solicitó el crédito para la compra de polos pantalones y faldas. El grupo  “La Prosperidad” agradecen a los inversionistas Kiva por el crédito brindado. Ever se encuentra en la parte posterior, es el tercero del lado izquierdo. Él viste polo color verde.En la foto no se encuentra la señora Karen Sheyla ya que por motivo de trabajo no pudo asistir.
texts.en:
This is the "La Prosperidad" [Prosperity] Community Bank, which is made up of 7 responsible and dynamic people.

This is the case of Ever, a young, 26-year old man who is single and trying to get his younger siblings ahead. For more than a year, he has been selling garments on the street. His desire is to have his own store and to continue growing in order to increase the volume of his products by the summer-fall season.

He applied for the loan in order to buy t-shirts, pants, and skirts. The "La Prosperidad" group is grateful to Kiva investors for the loan.

Ever is in the back row, third from the left. He is wearing a green t-shirt. Karen Sheyla is not in the photo, because she was unable to attend because of work.

loans.use: to buy t-shirts, pants, and skirts.

loans.name: José Toribio

texts.es:
José, de 31 años de edad, es un hombre con mucho espíritu de trabajo y deseos de superación, estudio hasta sexto grado, está acompañado y su pareja se dedica a las labores del hogar, tiene 4 hijos de los cuáles tres van a la escuela y el ultimo  tiene a penas 2 años. 

José, actualmente trabaja en una empresa constructora, reparando calles en el país, trabajando por periodos de tiempo y de eso recibe su pago mensual.- En algunas épocas se dedica a labores agrícolas, sembrando maíz, frijol, sorgo y hortalizas, todo esto le sirve para producir sus propios alimentos y con algunos excedentes de producción, adquiere un poco de ingreso económico extra. Las actividades agrícolas los realiza cerca de su casa, pero el trabajo en carreteras lo hace muy distante de su hogar.

El crédito lo necesita para comprar una vaca, porque en la producción de sus cultivos, siempre hay residuos de cosecha que podrían servir de alimento para animales y esto le daría otra fuente de ingreso, ya que son actividades que su familia fácilmente podría desempeñar a pequeña escala. 

Son muchas las proyecciones de José, pero unas más importantes que otras, lo primero que desea es incrementar sus ingresos y una forma de hacerlo es diversificar sus actividades productivas.- Su casa es de barro y en época lluviosa son afectados en su familia, es por eso que desearía construirla de otro material más seguro.- Además, pretende financiar y animar a sus hijos con los estudios, para que en el futuro, tengan una fuente de empleo estable.
texts.en:
Thirty-one year old José has great enthusiasm for his work and great ambitions to improve his life, despite having only a sixth-grade education. Today he is married and the father of four children, three of them in school and the youngest just two years old. José's wife cares for the children and manages the household. 

José currently works for a construction company, working on road repair projects across El Salvador and earning a monthly salary. He also grows a variety of crops during part of the year, such as sorghum, corn, beans, and other vegetables. Farming is thus a source of both food and additional income for José and his family. The plot of land that José farms is near the family's home, but the road repair work can take him very far away.   

José is applying for a loan for the purchase of a cow because he always has excess crops from the harvest that could serve as animal feed. José thus already has a food supply for an animal that could provide an additional source of income for his family. Managing a small farm and raising a cow are small businesses José, his wife, and their children can easily manage. 

Obtaining this loan and purchasing a cow would have many results for José, but his top priority is boosting his income. One way to do that is to diversify his business activity. The family's home is made of clay and uncomfortable during the rainy season, so José would like to renovate the house with stronger materials. He also wants to provide for his children's education and motivate them to study so that they'll have stable jobs when they grow up.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Bendera

texts.en:
Bendera is a married woman and she has four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Bendera's greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Bendera operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition in her business from other firewood operators. With this KES 25,000 loan, Bendera wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Famille Ndame Group

texts.fr: Etant donné que dans le milieu rural l'agriculture est la seule source de revenu principale et le café occupe une place de choix à IDJWI, Desiré et son épouse (voir photo) ont opté pour cette culture. Jusque-là les maladies qui touchent les plantes et l'incertitude de marchés sûres pour écouler les produits posent problème mais il estime qu'avec ce crédit il pourra entretenir son champ, pailler, acheter les produits phytosanitaires et payer la main d'oeuvre dans la perspective de voir s'accroitre sa production afin d'améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en: Given that agriculture is the only or main source of revenues in rural areas and that coffee  occupies a top spot at IDJWI, Desiré and his wife (see photo) have opted for this type of agriculture. Plant diseases and market uncertainty for the selling of products have so far posed a problem. But he believes that, with this loan, he will be able to maintain his field, alleviate the situation, purchase plant care products, and cover labor costs with the aim of seeing his production increase, so as to improve his family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to restore coffee plants

loans.name: Freddy

texts.es: Freddy es bien trabajador antes se desempeñaba como carpintero y albañil, ahora con un poco mas de esfuerzo también realiza trabajos de soldadura, labor que le permite mantener a su familia y su hogar. Freddy con su primer crédito logro realizar mejoras en el taller de carpintería en donde realiza muebles por encargo, solicita nuevamente el apoyo de crédito para reparar el techo de su vivienda, ahora que está muy pronto la llegada del invierno desea prepararse para vivir en buenas condiciones, con el financiamiento podrá compra los materiales como perlines y laminas de zinc para concretar la obra.
texts.en:
Freddy is a hard worker, an experienced carpenter and builder who invested the time and effort in learning to be a welder so that he can support his family and household. 

Freddy's first loan allowed him to make renovations to the carpentry shop where he makes furniture to order. He's applying for a second loan to repair the roof on his family's home as winter is approaching and he wants his family to live in greater comfort. Freddy will use the loan funds to purchase materials such as purlins and zinc sheeting that he needs to do the roof repairs.

loans.use: to repair the roof on his home so he can ensure a safe roof over his family as winter approaches.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy blankets, babies' clothes, shirts, and trousers to sell.

loans.name: Celestin

texts.en:
Celestin is 37 years old. He is married and has three children aged between the ages of 1 and 9, two of whom go to school. Celestin is a farmer and he has been growing rice for the past 12 years, while his wife is a businesswoman. With this loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers to grow rice. With the profits from the business he wishes to pay school fees for his children and to improve his welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow rice.

loans.name: Kavumbi

texts.en:
Kavumbi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past one year, selling maize flour. She faces a major challenge of machine breakdowns in her business.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase a  grinding machine for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a  grinding machine for her business.

loans.name: Tujyinama Group

texts.en: Tujyinama is a group led by Epiphanie, who is 31 years old. The group name means “togetherness” in English.  Epiphanie has a shop and has been in business for the past two years. With this loan, she would like to buy more pens, soap, and salt to sell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more pens, soap, and salt to sell.

loans.name: Mbodze

texts.en:
Mbodze is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. Her house has neither electricity nor piped water.

For the past year Mbodze has run a butcher shop from which she sells goat meat. Transportation is a major challenge for her.

Mbodze decided to join Yehu to access loans to help her business. She is applying for a 30,000 KES to buy goats to butcher and sell.

loans.use: to buy goats to butcher and sell.

loans.name: Nestan

texts.en:
Nestan is a 43-year-old married woman, from the village of Rukhi. She has two school-aged sons and a husband who works as a private artisan. His salary, however, is not enough to meet the basic needs of the family. 

With the help of her family members, Nestan is extensively engaged in agribusiness, which is the most important source of her family's income. For more than seven years, she has been involved in cattle and pig breeding, and in cultivation of nuts. They sell the agricultural products in the local market. 

As it becomes harder to earn a living over time, Nestan wants to expand her trading business in order to more effectively meet the daily costs of her family. A loan of 1100 GEL will be a great support to this hard-working woman and her family, enabling her to purchase all needed products and equipment to open a general store locally. 

She will serve clients herself and generate daily income that will cover her family's increased needs. Nestan and her family will be very grateful for having a chance to generate additional income and live in better conditions.

loans.use: To open a general store and get a stable source of income

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret cannot thank Kiva lenders enough for the great help they have rendered to rural communities, especially in fighting poverty. Margret's two previous loans were instrumental in advancing her business and improving her household status, thanks to the Kiva lenders.

Margret lives on the outskirts of Kyotera town with her husband and grandchildren. She deals in selling charcoal, drinks like beer, sodas, and spirits, and she also does agriculture. She works six days a week and each day she works for 12 hours. She started his business in 2009, with the aim of earning money to increase her family's income.

Margret is acquiring this loan to help her buy more stock, since sales are expected to increase during the Easter season. Her clients are traders from surrounding towns and her dream is to enlarge her business to the level of wholesale, but her biggest challenge is a lack of capital. Margret is described as a hard working woman. Thanks, Kiva lenders, for partnering with Margret.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and beer to sell

loans.name: Benewende 02 Group

texts.fr: Alizeta  est une femme cliente de ACFIME. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants.Elle travail à ACFIME depuis 5 ans. Elle a pour activités la vente des céréales: le riz, le sorgho le maïs. son activité prospère car elle une bonne stratégie d'écoulement des céréales, elle dispose d'un grand répertoire de client fidèles. Avec l’emprunt,elle pourra satisfaire ses clients. Alizéta et les autres membres du groupe ont un bon parcours à ACFIME. Ce groupe a bénéficié 11 fois du crédit à ACFIME et a bien remboursé. Après vente, son bénéfice lui permettra de renforcer sa capacité de vente elle pourra dégager plus de bénéfice et épargner plus.
texts.en:
Alizeta is a woman client at ACFIME. She is a married mother of five and has been working at ACFIME for five years. Her business involves selling grains: rice, sorghum, and corn. It is very prosperous, since she has a good strategy for selling grains. She has a large assortment of loyal customers. With this loan, she will be able to satisfy her customers. 

Alizeta and the other members of the group have a good record at ACFIME. This group has benefited from eleven ACFIME loan and indeed paid them back. 

After her sales, her profits will enable her to bolster her selling capacity. She will be able to make more profit and save more money.

loans.use: to purchase grains to resell: millet, sorghum, rice, ...

loans.name: Famille Saa Sita Group

texts.fr: Initié par son défunt père, Habimana s'est lancé dans la culture du café en 1985 lorsqu'il a terminé ses études secondaires. Le café est une source de revenu familial garantie quoique l'attente de l'écoulement du produit prend quelquefois du temps. Il espère pouvoir se construire une maison, acheter un autre champ et bien rembourser son crédit. Il est le chef de ménage et préside le groupe SAA SITA.
texts.en: Introduced to coffee farming by his deceased father, Habimana got started in this business in 1985 when he dropped out of secondary school. Coffee is a guaranteed source of family income, despite the expectations of selling the product, which may take some time. Habimana hopes to be able to build a house, purchase another field, and correctly pay back his loan. He is the head of household and presides over the group SAA SITA.

loans.use: to pay for weeding and harvesting

loans.name: Amale

texts.en: Amale is a 49-year-old Lebanese single woman living with her parents. Despite the bad circumstances, Amale is doing a great effort in cooperation with her father to be able to satisfy the family’s demands. She has owned a Minimarket since 2002. Today she is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner, Vitas s.a.l, to purchase merchandise for her business and to renovate her store. Amale is an optimistic person always aiming for the best and plans to receive more Kiva loans in the coming days to keep on improving her family’s standards of living.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her business and to renovate her store.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is thirty-nine years old, single with five children living in Kasese, Uganda. Lucy sells bitenge. She began the business using the proceeds from her salary. She also earns a salary and this has helped her look after her children by giving them basic needs. She has future hopes of expanding her business. Lucy is requesting a loan to buy wrapper clothing material, known as bitenge, to sell.

loans.use: to buy wrapper clothing material, known as bitenge, to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy crude salt from other salt miners for resale.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson, who is 51 years old, is a married male with eight children living in Kasese, Uganda. He used the previous loan to buy bananas and drinks to boost his business. He operates a restaurant and has been in that business for thirty-four years. He began the business to get profits and pay school fees for his children. He also practices farming to get additional income despite weather challenges. Out of his profits Wilson has managed to build rentals and is earning a living out of them. 

Wilson is working hard to generate income for his family. He needs a loan to buy building materials such as cement and bricks to add more rentals.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as cement and bricks to add more rentals.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses, 32, is married with two children. The family lives in Kasese, Uganda. While he runs a small grocery store, he mainly earns a salary as a teacher. He is a honest, hardworking man faced with the challenge of inadequate capital.

Moses is applying for a 1,500,000 UGX loan through HOFOKAM to buy construction materials such as cement and sand to build a house for his family. This is his dream.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to build a house for his family.

loans.name: Magdaleno

texts.es:
Para que la realización personal de alguien sea completa, se debe hacer lo que uno ama. Magdaleno es consciente de esto, y por ello cuando decidió a que profesión dedicarse, no dudó en la electrónica, oficio que aprendió cuando apenas era un adolescente, en medio de carencias y necesidades. Ahora, él es un profesional de calidad, que se apasiona en cada área de su trabajo. 

Magdaleno desea seguir creciendo en su carrera y aprovechar todas las oportunidades que se presenten. Por ello, él solicita un crédito para la compra de una motocicleta, que le servirá de ayuda para movilizarse con mayor rapidez a su trabajo. Porque, es el principal centro de ingresos para él y su familia.
texts.en:
In order to fully realize their potential, people must do what they love.  Magdaleno is conscious of this, and therefore, he did not hesitate when he decided on the profession to which he would devote himself—electronics.  He learned this occupation when he was barely an adolescent, amidst scarcity and need.  Now, he is a good professional who is passionate about every area of his work.

Magdaleno wants to continue growing in his career, and take advantage of all the opportunities that may arise.  For that reason, he is requesting a loan for the purchase of a motorcycle, which will help him to travel to work more quickly, because it is the main source of income for him and his family.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Alexander Josue

texts.es:
Alexander, de 23 años de edad, es un joven bachiller, que recientemente ha salido de estudiar y ha comenzado a trabajar en una empresa de almacenes, para poder llevar parte del sustento diario a su familia, está soltero y no tiene hijos.

Alexander, tiene menos de un año de haber ingresado a trabajar, pero aún así a logrado comprar una motocicleta para ir al trabajo, ya que antes tardaba demasiado en llegar a su lugar de trabajo.

Hoy en día Alexander, necesita dinero para reparar el techo de su casa de habitación y también comprar un repuesto para su motocicleta, ya que es su medio de transporte.

Alexander, desea seguir trabajando para ayudar a su familia y cubrir los gastos de su casa y en un futuro si es posible piensa continuar sus estudios superiores universitarios.
texts.en:
Alexander, 23 years old, is a young graduate who's recently finished high school and begun working at a warehouse company, so that he can contribute to his family's livelihood. He's single and has no children.

Even though he's been working for less than a year, he managed to buy a motorcycle to get to work, since otherwise with the commute he was arriving too late.

Right now, Alexander needs money to repair the roof of the house where he lives, and to buy a replacement part for his motorcycle which is his means of transport.

He wants to continue working to help his family and cover his home expenses, and in the future, if possible, he plans to continue his studies in college.

loans.use: to repair the roof of the house where he lives, and to buy a replacement part for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Nolvia Yessenia

texts.es:
Nolvia, de 30 años de edad, es bachiller y actualmente está casada y ya tuvo su primer hijo en el matrimonio, aún no va a la escuela.

Nolvia, esta trabajando desde hace un par de años en un almacén de electrodomésticos, donde con esfuerzo se ha ganado la confianza de todos sus compañeros y superiores.

Nolvia, necesita el crédito para reparar su casa, ya que todavía faltan cosas por hacer en la sala y en el dormitorio, con esto hará más acogedora la estadía en su hogar para ella y su familia.

Ella desea continuar sus estudios superiores en una universidad que esta cerca de su pueblo, pues su mayor sueño es convertirse en una profesional y tener un lugar importante en el mundo laboral.
texts.en:
Nolvia, 30, is a high school graduate and is now married. She has already had her first child in this marriage, though he does not yet attend school.  Nolvia has been working for a few years in a household appliance store where with effort she has earned the trust of all her colleagues and superiors.

Nolvia needs the loan in order to repair her house because she still has things to do in the living room and the bedroom.  This will make for a more welcoming stay at home for herself and her family.

She wishes to continue her higher education at the university near her town because her greatest dream is to become a professional and to have an important place in the work world.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Daviti

texts.en:
Daviti, 43, is a farmer who lives in the village of Chkheri. He is married and has two sons, one of whom lives abroad and works to send money to his family. His wife and he sell their produce in the local market. To cover daily expenses and even basic needs Daviti has also started working as a taxi driver and earns a modest income doing so.

Daviti has now been approved for a 1,600 GEL loan to buy equipment and tools and to have working capital to start making furniture. He plans to make chairs and sell them locally at a good price.

His loan comes within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This start-up loan program provides loans with easy conditions to small and informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan will greatly assist Daviti by enabling him to improve his economic situation, so giving his family a better style of life.

loans.use: to make chairs and sell them locally

loans.name: Luisa Amanda

texts.es:
Trabajar, para algunas personas, es la mejor forma para vivir una vida cálida y motivada. Doña luisa a sus 56 años es una mujer fuerte y emprendedora, dedicada a sacar adelante a su familia por medio de su negocio. Ella tiene 7 años de tener en su casa una venta de refrescos, la cual, inicio con una pequeña inversión de 300 córdobas y un termo, pero que ahora a crecido bastante, gracias al apoyo de su familia y clientela.
 
Doña Luisa solicita el crédito ya que desea invertir más en su negocio y comprar frutas y utensilios que usa en la elaboración de los refrescos. Sus metas y planes son mejorar su local,preparar profesionalmente a su nieta y ver a sus hijas como personas de bien.
texts.en:
Working, for some people, is the best way to live an enthusiastic and motivated life.  At 56, Doña Luisa is a strong and enterprising woman who is dedicated to getting her family ahead in life through means of her job.  For seven years she has sold drinks out of her house.  She started this business with a small investment of 300 Nicaraguan Córdobas and a thermos, but now it has grown quite a bit thanks to support from her family and customers.
